fields.headline: The prize quiz
fields.bodyText: As a young man William G Stewart's only real ambition was to be a Hollywood cowboy movie-star. Sadly a lengthy correspondence with "The Office of Cecil B DeMille" at Paramount Studios came to nothing. He ended up an army sergeant, a Butlins redcoat, a television producer and, for the last 16 years, a television presenter. Are you au courant with current affairs? A titan of trivia? Then try our daily prize quiz. Each week, a different guest quizmaster sets five questions per day, Monday to Friday. Send us your answers to all 25 questions at the end of the week and the first correct entry out of the hat will win a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.co.uk). E1 Which country produced (in Antwerp in 1920 and Paris in 1924) the last gold medal winner of the Olympic rugby competition? a) South Africa b) The USA c) France d) Great Britain E2 Nancy Astor, the first woman to take her seat in the House of Commons, represented which constituency? a) Falmouth b) Bristol c) Rochester d) Plymouth Sutton E3 Who was the first reigning British monarch to visit the USA? a) Edward VIII b) George VI c) George V d) Elizabeth II E4 On which planet are all the craters named after women? a) Neptune b) Venus c) Mercury d) Uranus E5 Television: CJ, the President's aide in The West Wing. What does the CJ stand for? a) Christine Janet b) Carole Julie c) Claudia Jean d) Charlie Jane Last week's answers to Julian Cope's quiz 1 2 3 4 5 A a d c d a B c d b d a C b b d d b D a a c a d E c c a d c Winner: RJ Hall, Camberley The full questions and answers are available on the Guardian website: www.theguardian.com/g2 · Entries must reach Prize Quiz, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday November 10. The winner will be notified by November 12. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at: www.theguardian.com/quiz
